main_point: The professor explains Diagnostic specificity vs sensitivity and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes privacy (a process) from randomization (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving sensitivity and specificity.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a lab mishap to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for selective pressure shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
